prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For continuum observations, we select 31 MHz, corredponding to 40km/s. For CO(2-1) line observation, we would like to invesitigate whether CO gas is detectable or not in debris disks. The velocity resolution of ~0.2km/s is enough to resolve the velocity width of 6km/s and identify the typical keplarian motion. In addition, we adopt ~0.2 km/s for avoiding the velocity smearing. Therefore we select 122 kHz for CO(2-1) line, corresponding to 0.16 km/s.

We will not aim at resolving the inner structure of debris disks, just for measuring total fluxes from continuum emission, so we will not need high resolution observations. The spatial distributions (dust continuum and gas) of debris disks are reported to be 2"-6" (e.g., Ricchi et al. 2014, Moor et al. 2013) from recent ALMA observations. Our setting is reasonable for mesuring the whole fluxes from the emission of debris disks.

Our science goal is to measure fluxes from the dust continuum emission. So, we define the sensitivity requirement based on the continuum fluxes. Our AKARI sources do not have information of 1.3mm data. In order to estimate peak fluxes of the sources, we used previous result of well-studied debris disk (e.g., Moor et al. 2013). According to the SED of this disk, the peak flux of the source is esimated to be ~10 mJy (e.g., Moor et al. 2013). Taking into account the differences of distances, we assume this value as the typical value of the debris disk. For Group1 sources, adopting the rms of 0.2mJy, S/N=50 is enough to make rubust SEDs at mm wavelength. In addition, this sensitivity will achive the detection limit of 0.7 earth mass (at the farthest source in Group2), which is an order of magnitude smaller than those of previous JCMT survey (Wyatt et al. 2003). For CO(2-1) line observations, we would like to investigate whether CO gas is detectable or not. We estimated the peak line flux from Kospal et al. (2013). S/N >10 is a valid criteion in deciding the detection of gas or not.

For continuum observations, we select 31 MHz, corredponding to 40km/s. For CO(2-1) line observation, we would like to invesitigate whether CO gas is detectable or not in debris disks. The velocity resolution of ~0.2km/s is enough to resolve the velocity width of 6km/s and identify the typical keplarian motion. In addition, we adopt ~0.2 km/s for avoiding the velocity smearing. Therefore we select 122 kHz for CO(2-1) line, corresponding to 0.16 km/s.

We will not aim at resolving the inner structure of debris disks, just for measuring total fluxes from continuum emission, so we will not need high resolution observations. Taking into account the differences of distances, we assume this value as the typical value of the debris disk. For Group1 sources, adopting the rms of 0.2mJy, S/N=50 is enough to make rubust SEDs at mm wavelength. In addition, this sensitivity will achive the detection limit of 0.7 earth mass (at the farthest source in Group2), which is an order of magnitude smaller than those of previous JCMT survey (Wyatt et al. 2003). For CO(2-1) line observations, we would like to investigate whether CO gas is detectable or not. We estimated the peak line flux from Kospal et al. (2013). S/N >10 is a valid criteion in deciding the detection of gas or not.

For continuum observations, we select 31 MHz, corredponding to 40km/s. For CO(2-1) line observation, we would like to invesitigate whether CO gas is detectable or not in debris disks. The velocity resolution of ~0.2km/s is enough to resolve the velocity width of 6km/s and identify the typical keplarian motion. In addition, we adopt ~0.2 km/s for avoiding the velocity smearing. Therefore we select 122 kHz for CO(2-1) line, corresponding to 0.16 km/s.

We will not aim at resolving the inner structure of debris disks, just for measuring total fluxes from continuum emission, so we will not need high resolution observations. The spatial distributions (dust continuum and gas) of debris disks are reported to be 2"-6" (e.g., Ricchi et al. 2014, Moor et al. 2013) from recent ALMA observations. Our setting is reasonable for mesuring the whole fluxes from the emission of debris disks.

Our science goal is to measure fluxes from the dust continuum emission. So, we define the sensitivity requirement based on the continuum fluxes. Our AKARI sources do not have information of 1.3mm data. In order to estimate peak fluxes of the sources, we used previous result of well-studied debris disk (e.g., Moor et al. 2013). According to the SED of this disk, the peak flux of the source is esimated to be ~10 mJy (e.g., Moor et al. 2013). Taking into account the differences of distances, we assume this value as the typical value of the debris disk. For Group1 sources, adopting the rms of 0.2mJy, S/N=50 is enough to make rubust SEDs at mm wavelength. In addition, this sensitivity will achive the detection limit of 0.7 earth mass (at the farthest source in Group2), which is an order of magnitude smaller than those of previous JCMT survey (Wyatt et al. 2003). For CO(2-1) line observations, we would like to investigate whether CO gas is detectable or not. We estimated the peak line flux from Kospal et al. (2013). S/N >10 is a valid criteion in deciding the detection of gas or not.

For continuum observations, we select 31 MHz, corredponding to 40km/s. For CO(2-1) line observation, we would like to invesitigate whether CO gas is detectable or not in debris disks. The velocity resolution of ~0.2 km/s is enough to resolve the velocity width of 6km/s and identify the typical keplarian motion. In addition, we adopt ~0.2km/s for avoiding the velocity smearing. Therefore, we select 122 kHz for CO(2-1) line, corresponding to 0.16 km/s.

We will not aim at resolving the inner structure of debris disks, just for measuring total fluxes from continuum emission, so we will not need high resolution observations. The spatial distributions (dust continuum and gas) of debris disks are reported to be 2"-6" (e.g., Ricchi et al. 2014, Moor et al. 2013) from recent ALMA observations. Our setting is reasonable for mesuring the whole fluxes from the emission of debris disks.

For Group2 sources, adopting the rms of 0.1mJy, S/N=100 is enough to make rubust SEDs at mm wavelength. In addition, this sensitivity will achive the detection limit of 0.7 earth mass (at the farthest source in Group2), which is an order of magnitude smaller than those of previous JCMT survey (Wyatt et al. 2003). For CO(2-1) line observations, we would like to investigate whether CO gas is detectable or not. We estimated the peak line flux from Kospal et al. (2013). S/N >10 is a valid criteion in deciding the detection of gas or not.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a survey of debris-disk candidates identified by the infrared satellite AKARI (Ishihara et al. 2015 A&A submitted) in Band 6 (1.3 mm dust continuum and 12CO(2-1)) at an angular resolution of 2". Our aim is to obtain better estimate for dust masses in these debris disks based on SED analyses and to search for gas in 12CO(2-1) line. The sample consists of 40 sources, observable from the ALMA site, out of 53 AKARI debris-disk candidates. 17 sources in our sample exhibit silicate features at lamda=9 and 18 micron, indicating that there is a significant amount of small dust grains around the stars. Furthermore, 10 out of these 17 sources have a stellar luminosity higher than 10 Lsun, requiring the existence of gas components detectable with the ALMA to sustain the smaller dust grains for a long period of time. This is the first survey of AKARI debris-disk candidates at millimeter wavelengths. The study will give us a clue for understanding the origin of gas in debris disks: the remnant gas from proto-planetary disks or the gas ejected from solid bodies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, Nagoya University
Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo
Graduate School of Science, Osaka Prefecture University
